J. Edgar Hoover.Action: Shows deep concern about his public image and professional reputation, clipping negative articles and sweating nervously.
Instructs staff politely to accommodate the PR writer by setting up a typewriter and showing personal photos.
Speaks respectfully and admiringly about Attorney General Palmer, emphasizing his strengths and heroism despite criticism.
Observes the careless investigators and is disturbed by their failure to preserve evidence properly, showing concern for order and detail.
Silently collects the bright pink handbills that contain violent revolutionary messages without protesting or alerting others, showing a reserved and cautious demeanor.
Makes connections and organizes information by mentally linking the severed finger to the blown open briefcase, showing early investigative insight.
Disturbed by investigators' careless handling of evidence (cleaning up blood instead of collecting it), indicating awareness of proper procedure though others disregard it.
Gathers and reads provocative hand-bills despite being a low-level clerk managing the filing system, demonstrating curiosity and proactive behavior beyond expected role.
Jumps back on his bike and pedals away holding the evidence (bright pink fliers) without alerting others, showing discreetness and confidence in handling sensitive material.
Lets out a laugh that leaves behind a smile; appears surprisingly warm.
Walks behind agent, reads his typewriter notes, engages in a thoughtful discussion about legacy and heroism.
Grabs young agent’s hand and holds it a bit longer, sizing him up; inspects agent’s handshake afterwards, seemingly pleased.
Tests the young agent by shaking his hand to assess his character.
Keeps the written pages to maintain control over information.
Engages the young agent with thoughtful questions about legacy and heroism.
Politely corrects secretaries on his name, jokes in a flirtatious but friendly manner with new secretary Helen Gandy, welcomes her to the Department of Justice.
Secretaries mock his grandiosity; he shares a warm glance with Helen before she leaves.
During D.C. race riots, watches police overwhelmed by crowds and treats it like a play, refusing to let it dampen his mood.
Corrects the secretary politely when she misnames him, showing attention to detail and confidence in his identity.
Attempts to show grandiosity with an overly familiar comment to the new secretary, which is mocked by others, indicating a social misstep.
Accepts the directive to attend the emergency meeting promptly, demonstrating obedience and professionalism.
Observes the race riots with detached amusement, ignoring the severity of the situation.
Ignores the old man screaming bloody murder outside his childhood home, refusing to let it ruin his cheerful mood.
Remembers mother petting him like a child, showing a moment of vulnerability and openness in memory.
Displays cheerfulness upon entering despite the chaos around him.
Ignores a screaming, manic old man and maintains his cheerful mood while entering his childhood home.
Demonstrates early ambition and confidence by declaring he could open an investigation at a young age.
Tells his mother he cannot take the Anti-Radical division job unless he is certain he can be effective.
Refers to his typist companion as very organized and plans to show her his card catalogue system, indicating a desire for simple, sincere connection.
Feels ashamed about smoking, showing self-awareness and respect for his mother's concerns.
Mentions he has trusted agents on his staff, indicating trust and reliance on others.
Avoids interacting with his father who is described as 'crazy', and pretends not to see or hear him.
Refuses to take a position unless he feels he can be effective, showing self-awareness and confidence in his capabilities.
Within four hours, compiles a list of forty suspected radicals and plans to have ten thousand by the end of the month, demonstrating skill, intelligence, and diligence.
Struggles with smoking as a coping mechanism, showing a moment of personal weakness or discomfort.
Prepares for a date by planning to show his card catalogue system, which is met with mild criticism, indicating social awkwardness or a narrow focus on work-related interests.
Engages Helen in a playful, intellectual game in the library, showing enthusiasm and sharing knowledge about the filing system.
Misses Helen's flirting signals, indicating a lack of social or emotional attunement in that moment.
Develops an innovative cataloguing system that drastically reduces search time from days to minutes, displays quick and accurate retrieval of specific information.
Remains unaware of Helen's flirtation, focusing solely on the task at hand.
Leans in awkwardly for a kiss, shows vulnerability and insecurity.
Gets down on one knee and sincerely compliments Helen's strength, character, and education.
Asks Helen not to share the moment with other women, showing self-consciousness.
Defensively insists he is a good judge of character and asks what flaw she sees in him.
Uses humor and familiarity by asking to be called Edgar as his mother does.
Reacts bruised but accepts Helen's refusal to marry and her focus on work.
With the precision of an army cadet, gets down on one knee and expresses his feelings with confidence and formality.
Speeds up his speech to kill a stutter and defensively tries to prove his skill at judging character.
Appears humiliated and unsure after being gently rebuffed by Helen Gandry.
Trusts Agent Smith and invites him to work in his private office rather than the outer office.
Mocks the Kennedy child with a crude remark about needing a fresh diaper.
Engages Helen Gandy in conversation, asking her opinion and expressing personal trust.
Neatly orders files into his private cabinet and locks it securely.
Carefully manages who is allowed close access, instructing staff to set up a trusted agent's desk in his inner office rather than outer spaces.
Maintains a bright and confident demeanor while educating a young agent rapidly and knowledgeably about the FBI’s history and powers.
Listens intently to mentor Palmer's aggressive tactics against radicals, shows awe towards power and control methods rather than empathy.
Takes detailed notes on suspected radicals including innocent ethnic groups, showing suspicion and lack of trust.
Notes Emma Goldman's radical speech with focus but no indication of tolerance or friendliness towards her views.
Compiles over 5,000 note cards on suspected radicals, diligently gathering intelligence.
Demonstrates awareness of political power dynamics, noting that no one shares power freely in Washington DC.
Sits attentively behind Palmer, learning from experienced superiors and absorbing information.
Notes figures like Emma Goldman and radical groups during public speeches, showing attentiveness and skillful information gathering.
Expresses desire to deport Emma Goldman without hesitation.
Silently watches the silhouette of an old man pass by, showing reservation and internal focus.
Remembers and recounts violent historical events emphasizing threat from radicals.
Poses as a fan to approach a man connected to Emma Goldman, displaying some social ease and interest.
Focuses intently on security measures, monitoring comings and goings in his office carefully and waiting breathlessly to observe an old man’s silhouette.
Attempts to have Emma Goldman deported, seeing this as a precedent-setting move.
Shows willingness to use intelligence gathering, as young Hoover goes undercover to gather information about Emma Goldman.
Ignores or dismisses the concerns about Emma Goldman’s citizenship that an agent raises.
Recalls historical violent events (Chicago strike, Centralia shootings) to justify his tough stance and vigilance.
The young Hoover’s approach to questioning a man at the jail is awkward and naive, coming off as a 'sycophant' rather than a capable investigator.
Assembles small, secretive team to aggressively investigate radicals; insists on extreme secrecy and trust no one, including fellow agents; focuses on pre-emptive surveillance.
Rejects installing locks to avoid drawing attention; designs a complex card index system for surveillance, showing meticulous organization and strategic thinking.
Dismisses concerns about targeting people for ideas rather than crimes; views plotting government overthrow as a crime justifying crackdown.
Proposes a simultaneous raid on all radicals to prevent them from going underground and planting bombs, showing strategic planning and foresight.

Designs a filing system that is deliberately non-alphabetical and compartmentalized to prevent leaks and make it difficult for unauthorized persons to access information, demonstrating intelligence and operational security awareness.
Insists on trusting no one, not even fellow agents, highlighting his cautious and discerning nature relevant to his role.
Disregards traditional definitions of crime focusing instead on intent and ideas to justify investigation scope, showing flexibility but also potentially risking overreach.
Taking objections personally and insisting on respect for the Bureau and himself (re: his unfashionable suit)
Publicly labeling Miss Goldman as dangerous and serving deportation papers immediately upon release
Firmly challenges a senior agent's skepticism and defends Bureau's actions showing confidence and assertiveness.
Unfashionable suit draws critical attention, indicating lack of awareness of appearance impact.
Introduces himself awkwardly to press, not fully commanding media attention.
Prepares detailed accusations and strategically uses distraction in courtroom, demonstrating careful planning and skill.
Examines Emma Goldman's ill-fitting dress in a way that distracts her, showing a calculating or intrusive behavior.
Sits directly in front of Emma Goldman during interrogation, implying an intimidating or confrontational stance.
Pauses with trepidation when Helen Gandy asks about Valentine's Day travel, indicating possible personal warmth or affection.
Approves Valentine’s Day travel arrangements with Miss Gandy, suggesting a friendly or kind connection.
Carefully preparing and overseeing formal interrogations with detailed accusations, maintaining composure when interviewees refuse to answer.
Sets legal precedents through strategic questioning and building cases for deportation.
Demonstrates organizational skills managing expanding file rooms with complex data connections.
Pauses with trepidation in personal interaction possibly indicating hesitance or lack of confidence.
Hands out firearms to his agents as gifts and encourages their use for violent raids.
Attempts to calm his nerves quietly by smoking a cigarette, showing private vulnerability.
Leads violent raids involving heavy police force causing bloodshed and broken bones.
Keeps a professional distance from Helen Gandy and the journalist during armed operations.
Leads coordinated, large-scale raids across multiple cities targeting subversive radicals, wielding many warrants and overseeing arrests.
Calms himself before operations by smoking a cigarette, showing some awareness of his nerves but also maintaining composure.
Personally arms his men with firearms and confidently addresses legal concerns about the use of weapons.
Is not naturally skilled with firearms, must conceal his awkwardness with guns in front of others.
Watches as officers beat a young radical, slows step, draws gun but does not intervene, then says 'That’s enough' to stop the violence.
Observes violence without immediate intervention, seemingly detached or conflicted about the brutality.
Defensive when questioned about past actions but tries to reassure Agent Smith about their importance.
Dismisses Mr. Toulson curtly and tells him to go away during a meeting.
Extends hand to Agent Smith to dispel tension after a difficult conversation.
Checks the hand he just shook with after agent Smith leaves.
Engages nervously and manically in conversation with Harlan Fiske Stone to calm his nerves.
Acknowledges his lack of social life, wife, or friends during conversation with Stone.
Calms his nerves by manically talking business when facing a intimidating superior.
Acknowledges the Bureau's poor reputation honestly and concedes to criticism without defensiveness.
Shows a lack of social connections (no wife, no pals) which might imply social shortcomings but does not undermine his professional focus.
Appears distracted by the fingerprinting affair, which a superior criticizes as shamelessly distracting.
Accepts the acting director position on conditions that promote merit and professionalism, showing commitment to fairness and integrity.
Walks down the aisle shaking each agent's hand in the FBI office.
Is humiliated by nickname 'Speed' and covers his discomfort, but does not retaliate or lash out.
Proposes centralizing fingerprint records to improve a disorganized system.
Responds calmly and covers his surprise professionally when unexpectedly offered acting director position.
Sets firm, principled conditions for accepting the acting director role, emphasizing meritocracy and independence from politics.
Seems initially unaware or caught off guard that he is nicknamed 'Speed' due to how he talks—potentially indicating a social blind spot.
Shakes each agent's hand personally, acknowledges their work as dangerous, promises reward for service.
Publicly criticizes an agent's facial hair and suggests he may be better suited for police work; dismissive tone.
Strictly enforces code of conduct against intoxicants and appearance; emphasizes eliminating any criticism of conduct.
Bears his father’s terrifying scream silently as his father dies.
Supervises installation of a personal telephone line in his bedroom, brusquely dismissing the workman’s question.
Smokes with his 12-year-old niece and corrects her about smoking.
Examines a sapphire ring from his mother at dinner, showing some acceptance of her affection.
Supervises installation of personal telephone line in his bedroom, controls situation without being questioned.
Responds confidently and authoritatively to niece’s naive remark on smoking.
Examines sapphire ring carefully, showing attention to detail.
Appears passive or subdued in interaction with mother regarding father's funeral and personal weight.
Returns a polite greeting and compliments a young man, but quickly withdraws attention and resumes his meal, appearing awkward and reserved.
Navigates a social situation with a potential informant, exchanges business cards discreetly, and maintains composure without showing overt interest.
Awkward verbal exchange revealing insecurity about educational credentials.
Rejects applicants who are unwilling to dedicate their lives long-term to the Bureau, despite good qualifications and family considerations.
Acknowledges and accepts a recommendation for Mr. Toulson despite coded implication of homosexuality, deciding to interview him.
Tries to change the subject after agreeing to interview Mr. Toulson.
Rejects majority of applicants swiftly, setting a high bar with a strict criterion of lifetime dedication.
Carefully considers recommended applicant Mr. Toulson despite initial reservations and unconventional traits for the time.
Attempts to change the subject when confronted with concerns about his leadership or image among potential agents.
Asks Helen Gandy to keep sensitive information in a confidential file, showing trust in her discretion.
Avoids discussing personal insecurities openly, indicating emotional guardedness.
Relaxed and focused during a tense conversation with Robert Kennedy, maintaining professional composure without warmth.
Creates and maintains highly confidential files marked 'Private and Confidential' and ensures sensitive information is securely handled with trusted aides like Helen Gandy.
Demonstrates guardedness and caution around sensitive information, indicating a careful and strategic approach to power and secrecy.
Engages with Robert Kennedy with a calm, focused demeanor, displays control and discretion regarding wiretap operations and confidential files.
Acknowledge personal insecurities (height) affecting how he is perceived by others, which might undermine his sense of authority but does not seem to impair his professional actions.
Attempts a conciliatory tone with Robert Kennedy, suggesting they can both get what they want and wage a war on two fronts.
Issues a veiled threat about the safety of the Kennedys, implying violent consequences to influence behavior.
Smiles creep into corners of his mouth after delivering a threat, revealing possible enjoyment in intimidation.
Calmly warns Robert Kennedy using historical precedent to emphasize the seriousness of the communist threat and attempts a conciliatory approach to cooperation.
Keeps a copy of sensitive transcripts in safe keeping, indicating foresight and preparation.
Inspects the fireplace and smiles subtly after delivering a veiled threat, demonstrating calculated confidence and control.
Has difficulty closing a window and drops his handkerchief, showing a minor moment of clumsiness or distraction.
Steps up on a platform to appear taller, feels embarrassed but allows a friendly handshake with Clyde Toulson.
Addresses Clyde’s application criticisms seriously and tries to maintain authority despite visible nervousness and stuttering.
Responds to Toulson’s questions about exercise routines with effort to engage despite making up answers.
Carefully responds to the credit director with calmness and insists on his true identity despite humiliation.
Decides to change and standardize his name on credit and other records to avoid confusion going forward.
Appears measured and deliberate when being fitted and choosing attire, signaling awareness of public image.
Expresses concern for fallen agents; acknowledges loss personally.
Focuses on threats and patriotic duty in staged, formal setting.
Wears a sharp 3-piece suit, presenting a confident and polished image consistently.
Immediately processes news of the massacre by confirming if a trusted agent is involved, showing attentiveness and concern for team members.
Handles staged filming in his office with professionalism and a strong public presentation, indicating awareness of image and communication skills.
Addresses a hostile audience trying to rally support against gangsters.
Disapproves clearly of Agent Jones' answer, signaling intolerance for perceived ignorance.
Focuses critically on a sweaty agent's physical flaws, seemingly dismissive and intolerant.
Disturbed by Lindbergh baby kidnapping, responds immediately, showing concern.
Orders officers to avoid trampling evidence, demonstrating protective vigilance.
Challenges the lead officer’s dismissal of evidence, indicating assertiveness but also potential distrust.
Responds immediately to a high-profile kidnapping case by ordering officers and traveling to the scene at once.
Carefully observes the crime scene and cautions officers against trampling potential evidence.
Questions the initial dismissive assumptions of the local authorities about the evidence, showing critical thinking.
Insists on proper handling of the crime scene despite resistance from local officers, asserting authority for the sake of investigation.
Dismisses Colonel Shwartkoff's actions as contamination of the crime scene, showing intolerance to mistakes but focus on accuracy.
Engages with Charles Lindbergh respectfully, explaining his forensic findings in a clear, sincere manner.
Identifies contamination of crime scene and demands removal of unauthorized personnel to protect integrity of investigation.
Displays technical understanding by analyzing the homemade ladder’s construction and its failure under specific conditions.
Engages Charles Lindbergh respectfully and seeks his opinion, showing social intelligence and confidence.
Claims presidential authority for access to evidence despite jurisdictional limits, which could be seen as overreach but also demonstrates assertiveness.
Carefully scrutinizes ransom note details, insists on evidence handling protocols.
Displays annoyance at Colonel Shwartkoff but remains careful in front of Lindbergh.
Shows concern for Lindbergh's son saying, 'I’m afraid for his boy.'
Firmly insists on obtaining letter and ladder despite local resistance.
Delivers a passionate speech urging stronger federal laws to protect children and aid law enforcement nationwide.
Feels weighed down by the burden of responsibility, hinting at internal concern or empathy.
Requests a copy of a file built on his assistant's wife, indicating possible lack of trust or invasion of privacy.
Waves down to Roosevelt as his car passes during inaugural parade.
Recognizes the complexity of the Lindbergh kidnapping case and recounts details about the criminals and intermediaries involved.
Does not take direct action in the excerpt, but demonstrates knowledge of the case's intricacies and background.
No clear mistake or failure observed in the text; he maintains confidence in recounting facts.
Provides full resources and prioritizes thorough analysis to solve the kidnapping case, emphasizing the importance of a child's life.
Dismisses notifying the Attorney General for approval, insisting on establishing the FBI lab with assertiveness.
Organizes the Attorney General's private library into a crime lab, quickly mobilizing resources and personnel to analyze kidnapping letters with scientific rigor.
Defies expected bureaucratic hesitation by preemptively establishing an FBI Crime Laboratory and asserting control over it, showing initiative and confidence in his capabilities.
Insists bills be marked by IRS at Lindbergh's home, taking control of the investigation.
Doubles pay of Albert Osborne and tells him he now works for his country.
Insists on marking the ransom bills through the IRS to track the money.
Doubles Albert Osborne's pay and reassigns him quickly to serve the investigation.
Questions alternative explanations such as Condon writing all notes himself, showing analytical thinking.
Promises Charles Lindbergh he will not pursue any lead until the child is safely returned, giving his word.
Assigns a 26-man team led by a special agent promptly to pursue the Lindbergh case, showing organized and decisive action.
Offers a personal assurance to Lindbergh that no leads will be pursued until the child is safely returned, demonstrating sensitivity and strategic restraint.
Acknowledges Lindbergh's distrust and respects his wish to conduct the search personally.
Reflects on the lack of respect given to the FBI at the time, indicating some understanding of others’ feelings.
Mentions that Lindbergh did not trust federal agents and wanted to handle the investigation his own way, reflecting an awareness of the situation's challenges and the public perception of the Bureau.
Acknowledges that nobody respected the Bureau then, implicitly recognizing limitations of the agency under his leadership at that time.
Acknowledges Helen Gandy with a polite, professional response.
Displays impatience and anger towards Old Toulson when challenged about wiretapping.
Determined to proceed with wiretaps despite ethical concerns raised by Toulson.
Confidently orders wiretaps authorized by the Attorney General despite opponent's hesitation, showing decisiveness and strategic thinking to prevent a perceived threat.
Displays fury when his reputation is questioned, potentially clouding judgment with emotion.
Demonstrates awareness of the risks and historical consequences of his actions, indicating a calculated and informed approach.
Waits patiently outside Roosevelt’s office, demonstrating calm and restraint despite nervousness.
Plays along with the waiting game to get his job, showing adaptability but not directly engaging others warmly.
Walks confidently into Roosevelt's office on time, holding a file and ready to fight for his job.
Plays along with the psychological game of waiting and intimidation practiced by others, showing self-control and strategic thinking.
Expresses trust and camaraderie by celebrating with Clyde and confiding a secret about increased surveillance powers.
Uses vulgar language to describe targets of surveillance and justifies breaking rules for security.
Carefully handled sensitive information, sought guidance from superior, and ensured he had legal cover for secret surveillance.
Displayed anxiety and uncertain laughter when discussing sensitive matters.
Broke rules by conducting warrantless surveillance, justifying it as necessary for safety.
Expresses a need for a trusted associate and offers a close, personal connection through regular meals despite work disagreements.
Selects and personally recruits a trusted subordinate to be his number two man, demonstrating awareness of loyalty and capability.
Engages in an intimate negotiation with the potential deputy, ensuring personal commitment and communication.
Shows devastation and deep concern for his mother's condition and the tragedy described.
Expresses belief that society is collectively responsible for lawlessness, indicating sense of accountability.
Enjoys the new attention from press, seemingly feeding ego.
Engages in private meetings with reporters to control the narrative and possibly manage perception.
Publicly promises to solve a high-profile case with full FBI resources within the year, demonstrating confidence and commitment.
Loves the new media attention and uses it to bolster his public image.
Engages a skeptical reporter privately to possibly influence or manage information flow.
Feels deep personal guilt and horror over a crime, reflecting emotional response rather than detached strategic focus.
Expresses desire for truthful representation of himself and the FBI, tamping down joy to maintain seriousness.
Seeks fame and recognition for himself and the FBI, shown through interaction with reporter and comic book promotion.
Insists on the truth being told about the FBI, avoiding embellishment or colorful exaggeration.
Subtly tampers down visible joy about potential fame, maintaining a controlled public image.
Insists on continuing scientific investigation despite opposition and limited resources; passionately defends the need for advanced forensic science to protect the nation.
Responds to the Attorney General’s criticism with visible anger and a sarcastic threat to expose their obstruction to the public.
Denies involvement with radio shows and comic books despite evidence, becomes uncomfortable, and lies to the Senator.
Responds politely and formally to aggressive questioning by Senator McKeller without losing composure.
Claims the Bureau runs at a profit and boasts about high-value recoveries and successes with notorious criminals.
Denies involvement in advertising and media production despite evidence to the contrary, showing discomfort and lying under questioning.
Demonstrates knowledge of his tenure and administrative role but avoids direct responsibility for arrests, indicating skill in bureaucratic management rather than fieldwork.
Shows anger and humiliation over a political attack, obsessively orders surveillance on Senator McKeller and seeks to punish Agent Purvis harshly despite practical objections.
Breaks a promise of lunch with Clyde but is internally breaking down and experiencing a panic attack.
Claims responsibility for many arrests and cases under his supervision, demonstrating confidence in his leadership role.
Immediately orders surveillance and investigative actions against Senator McKeller after a political attack, showing proactive and strategic thinking.
Demands harsh disciplinary action against Agent Purvis despite the political risks involved, indicating decisiveness and intolerance for mistakes.
Breaks a personal promise and isolates a colleague, suggesting difficulties managing interpersonal relationships under stress.
Exhibits signs of emotional breakdown and panic attack after confrontation, revealing vulnerability and potential limitations in emotional resilience.
Sits next to his sick mother's bed, expresses vulnerability and concern, wanting to take her to a doctor.
Kisses up to Agent Toulson with excessive praise, requiring others to follow his strict orders.
Agents nod out of duty, Toulson is uncomfortable indicating Hoover's leadership style may be more authoritarian than friendly.
Leads coordinated, aggressive arrest operations with focus and decisiveness, showing no hesitation in using force against criminals.
Coordinates a precise ambush on Karpis with multiple agents strategically positioned and executes the arrest efficiently.
Leads a rapid dawn raid arrest of gangster William Mahan, demonstrating active involvement and readiness.
Commands Clyde to 'blow it down' with a Thompson gun; Clyde hesitates but proceeds, leading to a dangerous exchange of gunfire which forces them to take cover.
Displays false modesty when crediting team effort on arrests.
Shows joyless behavior when playing with a toy badge, lacking genuine enthusiasm.
Laughs heartily when reading an affectionate, teasing love letter.
Mocks Lorena Hickok's personal traits and affairs with cruel nicknames.
Openly admits error in judgment about Lorena Hickok's romantic life.
Invites Clyde Toulson to join him on a covered vacation trip to the horse races as a thank you, attempts to make the offer appealing and considerate.
Confidently organizes a vacation and negotiations with colleagues to secure it at his expense, showing social skill and control over resources.
Demonstrates effective leadership by having the new FBI crime laboratory established, indicating strong organizational ability and vision.
Carefully studies the disassembled Lindbergh ladder, showing detailed attention and appreciation for Koehler's expertise.
Gives Koehler the funding to write to mills and track leads, indicating support and trust in his investigator.
Pauses to consider if Koehler is 'for real or really nuts', showing some skepticism but ultimately decides to support him.
Demonstrates insightful attention to detail by connecting complex forensic evidence and instructs a thorough investigation, showing clear strategic thinking and decisiveness.
Questions the wood specialist's request for more funding, momentarily skeptical but ultimately approves additional resources based on logical evaluation.
Engages confidently and wittily with the press and public, managing his image effectively at a high-profile movie premiere.
Demonstrates social skill and control by navigating elite social settings and organizing seating arrangements at an exclusive nightclub.
Explains the forensic details of the bullet wound clearly and confidently to an impressed audience.
Maintains secrecy when discussing sensitive case details, demonstrating awareness of propriety and confidentiality.
Successfully engages and influences a group of influential women through charm and controlled revelation of information.
Politely declines to dance and nervously tries to excuse himself, showing discomfort but no rudeness.
Feels humiliated by laughter but does not lash out; shows vulnerability by crying to his mother afterward.
Admits to disliking dancing with women and refuses to be publicly humiliated about it.
Feels unable to face his mother directly during a difficult conversation, showing vulnerability.
Uses his stutter cure method to speak with precision, diction, and clarity.
Expresses refusal to be publicly humiliated and articulates personal boundaries confidently.
Is unable to face his mother directly, only looks through the mirror, indicating emotional difficulty in confronting the situation.
Expresses strong belief in preserving traditional family morals in televised speech.
Focuses intensely on investigative details, leading others and making connections in the case.
Walks the halls with purpose and energized, directs agents quickly to pursue a lead.
Organizes a coordinated observational stakeout to track a suspect and gather evidence.
Leaps out of his car, pushes aside another officer, aggressively arrests a man based on evidence.
Handles evidence carefully and respectfully (treats audio tape like a fragile object).
Ignores urgent phone calls due to being absorbed in private, inappropriate behavior (listening to and possibly masturbating to a sex tape).
Eventually responds to the urgent news about the President's death with appropriate seriousness and acknowledgement.
Immediately calls Robert Kennedy to inform him about the President being shot.
Ignores flags at half staff and focuses on horse race during Kennedy's death.
Immediately contacts Robert Kennedy to inform him of the President being shot, showing prompt communication in a crisis.
Does not visibly respond to the flags at half-staff, focusing instead on a horse race, indicating possible detachment or distraction at a critical moment.
Edgar imitates a hat bouncing, making Clyde laugh and smile, and holds Clyde's hand without pulling away.
Expresses care verbally to Clyde: 'I care so very much for you.'
Does not look at Clyde when he confesses love and changes topic awkwardly.
Removes hand to reach for a drink he doesn’t need, interrupting physical connection.
Brushes his teeth with precision and spitting methodically, indicating careful personal grooming and routine.
Engages in lighthearted conversation with Clyde, using humor and charm, maintaining composure in a romantic setting.
Does not directly respond to Clyde's expression of love, averting eye contact and giving a brief 'Yes' when asked if he's okay, potentially indicating discomfort or evasiveness.
Removes his hand to reach for a drink he does not need, which could signal nervousness or a preparatory gesture, reflecting some internal uncertainty.
Attempts to steer the conversation obliquely by asking about Dorothy Lamour, shifting focus possibly to avoid difficult topics or awkwardness.
Engages in a physical and emotional confrontation that reveals vulnerability and complex affection towards Toulson.
Attempts to assert control and authority over Toulson through demands and criticism during conflict.
Shows reluctance and discomfort towards physical intimacy despite underlying feelings.
Maintains control and command during a heated personal confrontation and physically defends himself when attacked.
Attempts to assert authority over Toulson despite escalating tension, ultimately leading to physical violence and emotional outburst.
Rushes to the side of Old Toulson when he collapses and helps get medical attention.
Responds angrily to doctor's advice about reducing work hours, threatening retaliation if denigrated in front of staff.
Lets Toulson struggle with his spoon and facial droop without immediate help.
Leans in and peels the egg for Toulson after initially ignoring his struggle.
Appreciates and accepts the doctor’s flattery about his weight.
Discusses planting potentially false stories in the press as counterintelligence.
Expertly peels a hard boiled egg, demonstrating steady fine motor skills.
Uses knowledge of media and counterintelligence to plant stories strategically to discredit radicals.
Formulates a plan to deliver damaging evidence (hotel recording) timed before a major event (Nobel Prize) to maximize impact.
Dismisses concerns about legal risks from an associate regarding evidence use.
Shows little sympathy for ailing Toulson by initially ignoring his struggle, but later helps peel the egg.
Tosses his own yolk to his dog who’s been waiting expectantly.
Writes a fraudulent, harshly accusatory, and emotional drug-induced letter attacking someone as a 'colossal fraud' and 'evil, vicious one'.
Insists on continuing a ruthless plan despite advice urging caution.
Plans to send a fictitious letter from 'one of his own' to deceive a target, demonstrating strategic thinking and manipulation.
Ignores prudent advice about risks involved, showing disregard for caution which could lead to errors.
Injects amphetamines and writes a manic, emotional, drug-induced tirade, indicating impaired judgment and loss of control.
Focuses on expensive shoes rather than comforting Hauptmann's wife.
Patiently questions Hauptmann during interrogation without visible cruelty.
Observes surroundings thoughtfully during interrogation, showing professional curiosity.
Carefully reviews earlier drafts to check for Hauptmann's address, showing methodical investigation.
Observes seemingly irrelevant details like expensive shoes and the radio, indicating keen attention to environmental clues.
Focuses on Hauptmann's behavior and statements, demonstrating perceptive interrogation skills.
Notes Hauptmann's gaze out the window and investigates the garage, showing instinctive suspicion and thoroughness.
Mocks Bruno Hauptmann with a sarcastic comment about his wife's shoe collection while Hauptmann’s wife is having a nervous breakdown.
Interrogates Hauptmann aggressively, holding an empty ransom jar in front of him.
Dismisses Hauptmann's accusation of bigotry and distrust toward immigrants without addressing the concern.
Allows or oversees agents cuffing Hauptmann to a chair and interrogation accompanied by violence (punches, blows, screams).
Acknowledges a more cautious interpretation of handwriting evidence in discussion with Agent Jones, showing some openness to doubt.
Leads agents to dig up the garage floor and find a jar buried in a hole, demonstrating investigative thoroughness.
Confronts Hauptmann directly and confidently with evidence, asserting control of the situation.
Shows some bias by suspecting Hauptmann because of his immigrant status, reflecting possible flawed judgment.
Relies on a handwriting expert's analysis to connect ransom notes with Hauptmann’s writings, showing use of professional expertise.
Acknowledges Agent Jones’ valid critique regarding handwriting similarities, showing openness to alternative viewpoints and critical thinking.
Stands watch attentively while agents dismantle the garage, focused on small details and evidencing engagement with expert analysis.
Appears giddy with a man’s scientific exactitude, showing appreciation for expertise.
Displeased with a question that suggests doubt about Hauptmann's guilt and insists on the strength of evidence, showing intolerance for uncertainty or alternative views.
Directs focus on detailed forensic evidence, demonstrates understanding and reliance on scientific exactitude in the investigation.
Dismisses a question about the suspect confessing with impatience but relies on the clear evidence for indictment.
Takes a fist full of pills and gets more shots, indicating heavy amphetamine use while working.
Reflects thoughtfully on legacy and reputation, showing an awareness of the importance of narrative and history.
Keeps the curtains drawn and room dark, working or preparing in secrecy, demonstrating a controlled environment.
Insists Toulson stay and watch TV with him, showing a personal, controlled interaction.
Obsessively monitors and condemns Martin Luther King Jr., focusing on his perceived threats rather than his message of peace and justice.
Shows shame and shuts off the TV after realizing Martin Luther King Jr. has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, indicating some internal conflict or recognition of defeat.
Carefully observes the trial outcome and maintains confidence in the FBI's role and evidence despite external doubts.
Ignores or dismisses serious questions about the guilt of the defendant raised by notable figures.
Fighting exhaustion, trying to be warm when offering exclusive information to Ben Bradlee.
Dismisses concerns about Martin Luther King Jr., asserting communist ties and warning of anarchy.
Offers the exclusive recording to the press, showing awareness of media strategy and control over information disclosure.
Argues forcefully about the communist threat and crime rates despite lack of direct evidence connecting King to communism, showing a tendency to assert dubious claims confidently.
Fights exhaustion and tries to maintain warmth and composure during a difficult interaction, demonstrating persistence and professional commitment.
Rejects Ben Bradlee’s skepticism and insists on his own interpretation without acknowledging contrary evidence, indicating possible rigidity or closed-mindedness.
Engages candidly with Ben Bradlee, acknowledges criticism, shows some openness in conversation.
Is stunned and stung by Bradlee’s suggestion, indicating emotional sensitivity.
Persuades Ben Bradlee to seriously consider the threat and shows confidence in his own judgment about preventing bombings and violence.
Is visibly stung and stunned by Bradlee's critique about risking the FBI's reputation, indicating a moment of self-doubt or lack of control over the perception of his actions.
Grabs his mother’s pearls and holds them to his chest, slips on her dress, and has a complete emotional breakdown, showing vulnerability and connection to the only love he’s known.
Appears drugged out of his mind, isolated and alienated from the country he once knew, reflecting internal turmoil but no direct outward warmth.
Gets drugged out of his mind on amphetamine shots yet continues to perform duties, attending to presidential motorcades and meetings.
Shows emotional breakdown and vulnerability when dealing with his personal loss and memories of his mother, indicating possible emotional fragility impacting professional capacity.
Maintains routine and composure when called to meet the President, despite the passage of 40 years and visible signs of stress such as sweating, suggesting sustained ritualistic professionalism.
Shows vulnerability by sobbing alone in his office and admits fear of losing what he loves and built.
Invites retiring agent Clyde to a dinner at their old corner booth to reconnect.
Expresses distrust and fear about others (Nixon) potentially destroying his legacy and private files.
Maintains control over his private files by entrusting them to a loyal assistant, showing foresight about protecting sensitive information.
Appears emotionally overwhelmed and sobbing at his desk, unable to answer the phone or engage with staff immediately.
Refuses to acknowledge his partner Toulson's impairment and struggles to keep up.
Sits and eats with his nearly blind friend Toulson, showing some personal interaction.
Discusses expanding wiretaps on news reporters, rationalizing surveillance expansions.
Acknowledges the illegality of creating a private force but expresses concern over losing control.
Claims to never have played the political game of blackmail or intimidation, suggesting some personal integrity.
Responds harshly to his friend Toulson’s admission about possibly retiring ('Shut up, Clyde').
Refuses to acknowledge partner's impairment, maintaining professional distance.
Responds to query about sensitive files with a strategic denial ('What file, sir?').
Acknowledges need to expand wiretaps despite ethical reservations to prevent creation of a rival force.
Claims not to have played political games though admits some perceived rule bending.
Dismisses partner's suggestion of retirement firmly, showing resistance to change or vulnerability.
Claims credit for numerous high-profile arrests and actions that others actually accomplished, embellishes or fabricates details to enhance his personal image and legacy.
Attempts to assert control and loyalty even when confronted with the truth, indicating insecurity and a reliance on deception rather than genuine competence.
Maintains curated displays (e.g., Dilinger’s death mask) to reinforce his constructed image of being the heroic and central law enforcement figure.
Admits he was sweating because he needed Toulson and has never needed anyone else like that.
Sweats and accepts handkerchief from Toulson silently, showing vulnerability and trust.
Feigns indigestion to possibly avoid an affectionate moment.
Silently accepts accusation that he lied and exaggerates, showing a moment of honesty internally but not openly.
Takes credit for Hauptmann's arrest despite not being present at the scene, implying a desire for recognition over accuracy.
Recognizes his exaggerations and lies about an important event but struggles to admit fault openly.
Acknowledges needing Clyde Toulson’s help, showing self-awareness about his dependency.
Invites Old Toulson to dinner to discuss important matters, expressing reliance and concern.
Kisses Toulson’s forehead and holds the kiss for some time, showing affection.
Plays with his dogs and straightens his mother's portrait, showing tenderness and sentimentality.
Attempts to maintain control and composure despite emotional struggles, straightening a portrait of his mother to restore order in his environment.
Expresses inability to depend on anyone at the Bureau, indicating a decline in trust and possible isolation in his professional environment.
Shows awareness of his need to discuss important matters with a trusted confidant, indicating prioritization and foresight.
Keeps a private collection of intimate, personal items reflecting hidden aspects of his identity.
Keeps a lesbian love letter to Eleanor Roosevelt close and reads it often, recalling it with laughter.
Toulson lovingly closes Hoover’s eyes after his death, indicating a sense of care from those around him rather than Hoover's own warmth directly.
Maintains a vast collection of secret files and hidden personal artifacts, indicating careful control and secrecy.
Keeps unfinished work and sensitive materials (such as the King's sex tape transcript and a file on Eleanor Roosevelt) close at hand, demonstrating thoroughness and preparedness.
His office is immediately sealed and searched after his death, implying his work and legacy were taken seriously and considered significant.
Leaves private files that are secretly destroyed by his assistant after his death.
Maintains a lifelong close relationship with Clyde Tolson, who inherits his estate and honors his memory.
Built and created the FBI, which is regarded as the finest law-enforcement agency in the world.
Maintained private and personal files that remain largely unknown and were hidden even at the end, indicating careful control of sensitive information.
Allowed his private filing cabinets to be taken and destroyed after his death, which could imply a failure to secure his legacy or protect his sensitive materials from exposure.
